content:
**"Policy Schedule"** means the document issued by Us which reflects details of You, Your Maid and/or any terms and conditions that are specific to the Policy.

**"Pre-Existing Conditions"** means an Injury or Illness which existed before the Effective Date of Cover:
i. which You or Your Maid knew about before the start of the Policy; or
ii. which Your Maid have received diagnosis, medical treatment or prescribed drugs before the start of the Policy; or
iii. for which Your Maid are under investigation and awaiting result before the start of the Policy; or
iv. for which Your Maid have been advised to get medical treatment by a medical practitioner before the Start of the Policy
or should reasonably have been aware, based on normal medically accepted pathological development of the Injury, Illness or Disease.
questions: How does the definition of Pre-Existing Conditions affect coverage eligibility when an illness was diagnosed but treatment was not yet started before the Effective Date of Cover?
In what ways can the Policy Schedule specify terms and conditions that override or supplement the general definitions of Pre-Existing Conditions?
If Your Maid was advised to seek medical treatment before the Policy Start but did not follow through, how does this impact the classification of the condition as Pre-Existing?
How does the policy treat an Injury or Illness that was under investigation with pending results before the Effective Date of Cover in terms of coverage and exclusions?
What documentation is required to prove whether a condition existed before the Effective Date of Cover, especially when the condition was only suspected but not diagnosed?
How does the policy handle situations where You or Your Maid should reasonably have been aware of a condition based on medically accepted pathological development prior to the Policy Start?
If a condition was unknown to You or Your Maid but medical records indicate prior diagnosis or treatment before the Policy Start, how does this affect claim validity?
How does the inclusion of Your Maid in the Policy Schedule influence the application of Pre-Existing Conditions definitions and coverage?

What are the implications for coverage if an Injury or Illness was diagnosed after the Policy Start but symptoms were present and should have been reasonably recognized before the Effective Date of Cover?
How does the policy differentiate between Pre-Existing Conditions for You versus Your Maid, and are there any specific exclusions or conditions that apply differently?
In cases where Your Maid is awaiting medical test results before the Policy Start, how does this pending status affect the coverage of related claims?
How does the policy address conditions that Your Maid was advised to treat before the Policy Start but treatment was delayed or refused?
What role does the Policy Schedule play in documenting any waivers or special terms related to Pre-Existing Conditions for You or Your Maid?
If an Injury or Illness was treated with prescribed drugs before the Policy Start, how does this influence the classification as a Pre-Existing Condition and subsequent claim handling?
How does the policy interpret the phrase 'should reasonably have been aware' in the context of Pre-Existing Conditions, and what evidence is required to support this?
What are the consequences if a Pre-Existing Condition is not disclosed in the Policy Schedule or during the application process?
How does the policy handle claims for conditions that developed from an Injury or Illness that was not diagnosed but was symptomatic before the Policy Start?
In what ways can the Policy Schedule reflect specific terms that modify the general definition of Pre-Existing Conditions, such as exclusions or coverage extensions?
How does the policy treat Pre-Existing Conditions when Your Maid has received medical treatment overseas before the Policy Start?
What is the impact on coverage if the Policy Schedule includes Your Maid but does not explicitly mention Pre-Existing Conditions related to her?
